repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Private Sector Development,
            Private Sector Development and Capacity Building, Public
            Resource Management, and Fiscal Reform Support Credits

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Private Sector
            Development Credit (PSDC) and the Private Sector Development
            and Capacity Building Credit (PSDCBC) for Mauritania, was to
            accelerate private sector development (PSD) by addressing
            the constraints still remaining after the resumption of
            adjustment efforts in 1992. The four operations aimed at
            promoting the development of the private sector as a major
            engine of growth and at improving public resource management
            to reduce poverty. PSDC and its accompanying technical
            assistance project, the PSDCBC, addressed three areas: (i)
            costly delays in implementing key reforms in the banking and
            fisheries sectors; (ii) a lower than expected supply
            response from the private sector; and (iii) persistent
            weaknesses in public resource management. The Public
            Resource Management Credit (PRMC) of 1996 addressed the
            following: (i) strengthening of economic management,
            institutional capacity, and governance; (ii) public resource
            management through a reform of the indirect tax and trade
            systems; and (iii) the restructuring of expenditure in favor
            of the social sectors. The Fiscal Reform Support Credit
            (FRSC) of 2000 aimed at: (i) extending the tax reform to
            direct taxes to promote PSD and improve Mauritania's
            competitiveness on world markets and (ii) deepening
            expenditure restructuring.

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Private Sector Development
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Sector
            Development Credit Project in Mauritania are as follows:
            overall outcome of the project was rated satisfactory, and
            the performance of the Bank and the Borrower were also as
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            are: 1) devote adequate time and effort to build
            understanding and ownership of reforms at both the political
            and the administrative levels, and effectively involve the
            Borrower in supervising the reform program; 2) carefully
            assess the sequencing and timing of the reform program and
            explicitly link the corresponding institutional support to
            the implementation timetable of the reform program; 3)
            maintain continuity within the Bank team throughout
            preparation, appraisal end supervision, and carefully build
            and maintain relations with counterpart staff, working with
            them as a team; and 4) ensure there is good coordination
            with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and donors, right
            from the beginning.

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Private Sector Development
            Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Private Sector Development Credit
            Project will support the structural measures needed to
            accelerate the development of the private sector, strengthen
            the financial sector, and promote growth notably in two
            sectors where private sector activity is promising: fishing
            and mining. The credit will support a program of policy
            reforms which are necessary for establishing an environment
            conducive to supply-response and self-sustained growth of
            the private sector. The reform program includes: (i)
            unification of foreign exchange rates; (ii) strengthening
            the legal and judiciary environment through, inter alia, the
            revision of legal codes pertaining to business and the
            training of judges and lawyers; (iii) reorganizing the
            accounting and audit profession, strengthening the minimum
            requirements for qualification and revising the accounting
            plan; (iv) empowering the Chamber of Commerce and
            strengthening it so it can represent private sector interest
            vis-a-vis the authorities and help provide needed services;
            (v) adopting and continuously enforcing new Banking Law to
            ensure sound banking practices are applied; (vi) continuing
            the regular issue of Treasury bills and the movement to
            indirect instruments of monetary control; (viii) formulation
            of a strategy for the second phase of financial sector
            development; (ix) strengthening the surveillance of fishing
            activities; (x) strengthening supervisory and research
            institutions in the fishing sector; (xi) disengaging the
            State form production and marketing of fishing activities;
            and (xii) strengthening the framework for mining sector
            development, including the revision of the mining code and
            taxation applied to mining, reorganization and strengthening
            of supervisory and regulatory institutions, and revision of
            cadastral procedures.
